title: Analysis | Were 300 new rules issued in just one week by President Obama? Nope.
subtitle: House Majority Leader Kevin McCarthy's office quickly reversed course after being contacted by The Fact Checker.
author: www.washingtonpost.com
vclaim:
The reader did not think that the claim of “300 rules” was possible. The blog post linked to a Daily Caller article, which in turn linked to a government Web site called regulations.gov. Upon close examination, it turned out that the 300 “rules” included 277 “notices” of things such as a meeting scheduled by the National Institutes of Health. There were 31 proposed rules, most of which were minor in nature.

But a rule is only a “rule” when it is issued in final form. The Federal Register, which is a more authoritative source, indicates that between January 1 and January 8, 2015, federal agencies issued a total of 53 final rules and 69 proposed rules. (Here’s a summary from one day, Jan. 5.) Most of these are administrative in nature; only 13 of the 53 final rules were considered “significant” under Executive Order 12866, issued by President Bill Clinton in 1993.

Among the standards set by Clinton, as well as the Congressional Review Act of 1996, the federal government is required to identify regulations that could have an economic impact of more than $100 million, but people frequently misunderstand what that means. It does not necessarily mean $100 million in costs; in fact, it can also mean more than $100 million in benefits.

Moreover, other factors can result in a rule being deemed as major, such as: it transfers funds from one party to another (grants are one example); it results in consumer spending; or it sets up fees for federal functions (such as issuing passports). In the Obama administration, 83 major rules were issued in 2009, 100 in 2010, 80 in 2011, 68 in 2012 and 78 in 2013, according to a recent Congressional Research Service report.

So you can see why our reader was puzzled by the assertion of “300 rules” in just seven days.

We reached out to Matt Sparks, McCarthy’s press secretary, and asked about the blog posting. Very quickly, he informed us that the blog post had been replaced with a new headline and item, along with a prominent correction:

Correction: This post has been updated (original title: “One Week, Three Veto Threats, 300 New Regulations”) to correct for an inaccurate count of regulatory activity in the first week of the new year. The original post stated that the Obama Administration issued 300 regulations in the first seven days of 2015. This count incorrectly included items that have little to no impact on the regulatory burden facing Americans, such as notices and some proposed rules.

Certainly McCarthy’s office should have double-checked before running with “facts” from an inaccurate article. But this kind of quick and forthright response warms The Fact Checker’s heart. As such, we will not be issuing any Pinocchios.

Updated: As this column was just going up on the Web, Rep. Lynn Jenkins (R-Kan.) repeated the line about “300 rules” at a news conference. Spokesman Tom Brandt said she had gotten the number from McCarthy’s blog post, but her office also quickly corrected her statement on her Web site.
